trainingInfo.name: Give Your Paw
trainingInfo.description: Give Your Paw may be the most natural trick for dogs prone to pawing. This one is especially important because it serves as the foundation for other paw-oriented tricks, so master it first. The shaping steps for teaching Give Your Paw are:

steps.step: Find out what usually gets your dog to paw at you and use it to get him to do it. As your dog's paw is in the air, click and treat.
Repeat this fifteen to twenty times until your dog is offering his paw readily.
Now, leave your hand outstretched and wait your dog out; don't prompt him in any other way, just see what happens. If he lifts his paw at all, click and treat.

If after a few seconds he does not lift his paw, go back to helping him for another ten to fifteen repetitions before you try again. You want your dog to understand that lifting his paw is what gets the click and treat to happen.

If you are using your outstretched hand as a prompt that gets your dog to give his paw, this can be turned into the cue for the behavior. Show your hand and click and treat your dog as he is stretching out his paw.
Add the verbal cue Give Your Paw when your dog is raising his paw to slap your hand on a regular basis.

Practice in different environments with various distractions, being careful not to overwhelm your dog. If the behavior falls apart in the new place don't be afraid to make things easier for him and help him out.

Avoid repeating yourself over and over; give one cue, wait for your dog's response, and click and treat. If your dog's response is not quick enough, go back to helping him for six to eight repetitions before trying again.

quickFix.problem: Encourage Your Dog to Give Her Paw:
quickFix.solution: If your dog does not uaually raise her paw, try teasing her with a really yummy treat in your fist held at about nose height, scratching her on the chest, or touching her toenails with your finger. Most dogs will respond by raising a paw, giving you an opportunity to click and treat.

trainingInfo.name: High Five
trainingInfo.description: The High Five is just a variation of the the Give Your Paw trick with a few minor adjustments.

steps.step: Teach your dog to target your hand with her paw for a click and treat.

Present your hand as the target in various positions until you can hold your hand up, palm facing the dog with fingers toward the ceiling. Click and treat your dog for touching your hand with her paw.
Practice this until your dog is quickly raising her paw when she sees you put your hand up.
Verbally label the behavior High Five when it is happening on a regular basis.
Add in distractions and work on having her do it with other people as well.

tips: Mind Your Cues: - Sometimes you'll want to use a different cue or hand signal than the one you started with when you are teaching tricks. There is an order that must be followed before your dog will preform the behavior on the new cue. You must present the new cue before the old cue or the dog will not pay attention to the new cue.

trainingInfo.name: Wave
trainingInfo.description: Teaching your dog to Wave is not only adorable, it's also an effective way to boost doggie PR, because it gives him an appropriate way to greet people. Establishing an accountable behavior, such as waving, is one of the keys to eliminating jumping on visitors. To preform this trick, your dog must raise a paw in the air while remaining stationary. You can teach him to do this by using a combination of targeting and shaping. The shaping steps are:

steps.step: Start with your dog in a Sit/Stay and move a few steps away from him. Go back every few seconds for a full minute to reward your dog for not following you.
Standing in front of your dog, ask for his paw and click and treat him for giving it to you several times in a row.

Take a step away from your dog and ask for his paw. Click and treat the slightest effort to raise his paw without trying to move toward you. You may need to reward him for staying for a few repetitions before he'll remain in position and lift his paw.
As your dog raises his paw to place it in your outstretched hand, start fading this cue by removing your hand quickly. Click and treat your dog for swiping the air.
Repeat this step until your dog starts raising his paw when he sees your outstretched hand.
As your dog starts to offer swiping the air readily without moving forward, you can begin to verbally label this new behavior Wave.

Change the hand signal to actual wave by changing the position of your hand from the outstretched palm to a waving hand. Offer the new cue (the waving hand) right before the old cue (the outstretched hand), gradually fading out the old cue until your dog is preforming the behavior when you are waving at him.
Add in distractions and practice in new places until the behaior is reliable.

tips: Calm Canines: - Training involves many elements, but there are two things to remember. First, make the most of your dog's natural behavior by combining it with tricks that you put on cue, as the paw tricks demonstrate. Second, teach your dog the behavior you want him to preform, like sitting, in the presence of other people or dogs. The following tricks will help your dog remain calm, and will put your guest at ease, too.

trainingInfo.name: Bow
trainingInfo.description: Teaching your dog to Bow on command not only makes for a flashy trick, it can also help you to put a visiting dog at ease. Dogs invite each other to play in this position and it can be an excellent way for your dog to learn to make friends. To preform this trick, the dog starts from a standing position and lowers the front half of his body until his elbows touch the floor.

steps.step: Start your dog in a standing position; hold your hand below her chin (about three inches) and get her to touch your hand, then click and treat.

Gradually make it harder by placing your hand closer to the ground in increments of several inches each time. Click and treat your dog for making an attempt to lower her head further to touch your hand.

When your hand is resting on the ground, click and treat your dog for touching it with her nose without lying all the way down. If your dog continually lies down, raise your hand by several inches for a while before continuing.
Make sure you watch your dog carefully and click and treat any effort she makes to bend her elbows.
Once your dog will lower her top half, start giving her less help by removing your target hand before she touches it.
Fade the hand target until she drops her head when you just begin to make the motion with your hand.
Increase the difficulty by only clicking and treating those repetitions where she lowers her head fast.

Increase the difficulty by increasing the duration (length of time the dog holds the behavior) by adding Hold It or Stay command. To increase the duration of the behavior, delay the click by one or two seconds and gradually increase the time.
Add a verbal cue like Bow just before she preforms the behavior.
Take it on the road and preform in new places.

tips: Click and Treat Frequently: - In order to make progress in trick training, you need to work at a pace where the dog is getting clicked and treated frequently. As you increase the difficulty of a trick, try not to let the dog make more than two or three mistakes before you show him what you want him to do.

trainingInfo.name: Play Dead
trainingInfo.description: Teaching your dog to Play Dead is a show-stopping trick that is sure to make even non-dog lovers to sit up and take notice. this trick requires the dog to lay on his back with his paws in the air and hold it until released.

steps.step: Get your dog to lie down, then click and treat.
Use a treat to roll your dog onto his side, then click and treat.
Fade the lure by doing six repetitions in a row and then trying the seventh repetition without the lure, clicking and treating the dog for preforming the behavior.
Reintroduce the lure to get him to roll onto his back, then click and treat. Fade the lure after the sixth repetition.
Go back and put all three steps together so that he preforms them all in one continuous motion for one click and treat.

Fade the lure by working with food for six repetitions then without food for two repetitions. Go back and forth until your dog responds the same with or without food. Note: The way you hold your hand will become the exaggerated cue that starts the behavior.
Change the old cue to a new cue by offering the new cue before the motion you used to get the behavior started. Pointing your thumb and forefinger like a gun and saying 'bang!' is very flashy!

Work on speed by only rewarding the dog for quick responses to the new signal. Decide on how many seconds he has to start the behavior and click and treat even before he finishes. Clicking in the middle of the behavior is what builds speed.

tips: Quick Review: - Stay with your dog first; then gradually give the cue for the behavior at greater and greater distances, only moving further away if the dog preforms the behavior reliably. Don't be afraid to do remedical work with Stay if the behavior seems to fall apart.

trainingInfo.name: Belly Up
trainingInfo.description: This is simular to the Play Dead trick except that it is also involves allowing someone to touch the dog while she is flat on her back. Not all dogs are comfortable with this, so know your dog well before asking for it in front of strangers.

steps.step: Have your dog Lie Down, then click and treat.
Lure your dog onto her side, then click and treat.
Lure your dog over onto one hip, then click and treat.
Lure your dog all the way onto her back, then click and jackpot (give a large number of small treats) the first time and quit the session.

Once your dog is rolling onto her back easily, fade the lure after six repetitions and see what happens. If the dog preforms the Belly Up behavior, click and treat. If not, lure her six more times and try again.
When your dog is readily rolling onto her back, call it Belly Up just before she offers the behavior.
Delay the click once your dog is in the Belly Up position by at first a few seconds and then more and more until she will hold the position for longer periods of time.
Add in touching her belly, and click and treat her for holding the Belly Up position while you do this.
Add in the distraction of strangers touching her belly, and click and treat her for holding the Belly Up position while being petted.
Take it on the road. Practice in new places with new people. Don't be afraid to help your dog into position is she gets confused in a new place.

tips: Introduce an Audience: - Although some of your training is behavior modification, some of it is just plain fun. Once you've trained a well-behaved, socially acceptable dog, let everyone in on the games!

trainingInfo.name: Roll Over
trainingInfo.description: As you train this trick, pay close attention to your dog to be sure he's not hurting or twisting his back. If, despite your best efforts, your dog refuses to get on his back, skip this trick and try another. Your dog may be sore or uncomfortable and this may be his only way to express it. It is always important when training a dog to listen to what she is telling you!

steps.step: Get your dog to lie down with his belly touching the ground, and click and treat.
Use a treat or a toy to turn your dog's head until he flops over on one hip, and click and treat.
Use a treat or toy held close to your dog's shoulder to get him completely on his side, and click and treat.

Gradually move the treat or toy, while he's chewing on it, to move him onto his back and then eventually all the way over. This step often takes many attempts before the dog is comfortable enough to be on his back.

Click and treat small efforts to move toward the treat at first before you get him to move further to get his click and treat. If you make it to hard to earn a click your dog will quit on you and think it's no fun.
When your dog is rolling over easily, it's time to start fading out all the extra cues and make him offer more before you click.

Once he can roll over with just this little bit of help you can begin to label this trick verbally as Roll Over. Whatever you are doing with your hand or fist could be a hand signal for the behavior as well.
Add in distractions one at a time and be prepared to help him complete the trick if he has trouble concentrating.

tips: Roll Over: - Roll Over requires your dog to lie down flat on his stomach, roll all the way over, and get back on his feet. Though the concept is simple, this is not always an easy trick for your dog to preform. Long-back breeds like Dachshunds or Basset Hounds may not be as good at this trick as other breeds due to the way they are built.

Obstacles to Roll Over: - Dogs with long backs sometimes find it uncomfortable and awkward to roll over on their backs and then try to get back on their feet. Over-weight dogs or dogs that have had back injuries in the past may also have difficulties.
Use a Soft Surface: - If possible, teach the Roll Over trick on a soft surface like a towel or carpet so your dog is more comfortable.

trainingInfo.name: Spin
trainingInfo.description: Spinning involves your dog turning in a complete circle in either direction. As your dog gets good at this, you can have her keep spinning until you tell her to stop. You can teach Spin with free shaping or a lure. For a beginner, it is probably easier to teach with a lure. You can see the results more quickly and will be more motivated to want to train more often. Feel free to add more steps to the shaping plan if you feel your dog needs more help in understanding what you want him to do.

steps.step: Use your hand as a target and with your dog facing you, get her to follow your hand a quarter of the way around, then click and treat.
Now, leave your target hand at the quarter-way mark and wait until your dog touches it with her nose on her own before you click and treat. Practice this until she's offering it readily.
Next, just before she touches your hand, move your target hand to the half way point and click and treat your dog for following it, but before she actually touches it.
At this point, as you drop your hand she may spin the rest of the way around, but continue to click and treat for the halfway point in order to build speed.
Use your target hand to start the dog turning, but then pull it away quickly. Click and treat your dog for attempting to turn without the target to guide her.
Time the click so that you're clicking the dog for being at the halfway point.
Continue to minimize your target hand and click the dog for continuing to turn without your help.
Fade the target hand to just a motion to the left or right.
Fade the target to a simple left or right cue. A pointed index finger would be appropriate as a final signal.
Once your dog is beginning to spin as you start to move your hand, you can begin to add a verbal cue to your hand signal by saying 'Spin' first, and then offering the signal.

Once you and your dog have mastered ten in a row, you can begin working on speed. Set a time limit in which your dog must preform the behavior, and click and treat only those repetitions that meet the goal. To train your dog to spin in the other direction, simply go back to the first step and work your way through all the steps again.

quickFix.solution: If at any point the spin trick becomes slow or begins to fall apart, drop the verbal cue (don't ask for the behavior). Go back to luring your dog for a few repetitions, and then fade the lure until he is preforming Spin quickly and reliably. Add the cue back in when your dog's behavior is the way you want it.

tips: Use a Target Stick: - If you've tried to teach this trick using a lure or food treat, you probably realized how difficult it is to get rid of the lure. Instead, use targeting either with your hand or with a target stick to show your dog what you want her to do.

trainingInfo.name: Are You Scared?
trainingInfo.description: This trick will put a smile on everyone's faces, especially children's. To indicate his 'fright,' the dog runs under a table or bed and peeks out from under the tablecloth or bedspread. The shaping steps for teaching this trick are as follows:

steps.step: Start with your dog under a table, and use your voice or a treat to get him to peek out. click and treat.
Make sure you time your click for when he first pushes out from under the cloth.
Repeat this six to eight times and then try putting him under again and waiting to see if he offers peeking out on his own.
Once your dog has this down, teach him to go under the table using a target lid.
Bait the target with a treat at first to encourage him to go under the tablecloth and click and treat each time.
Take the bait off the target but leave the target under the table or bed and send him again. Click and treat your dog for going under the table or bed for the target.

To get the peeking behavior, repeat the above step (getting him under the object) until your dog offers it readily and then delay the click. When your dog doesn't hear the click, he will probably come back out to see what's wrong. Click and treat him just as he peeks out from under the cloth.
Repeat this until he runs under and peeks out readily; then verbally label the behavior Are You Scared?

quickFix.problem: What if My Dog Doesn't Peek:
quickFix.solution: If you're having trouble getting your dog to peek because he runs all the way out from under the tablecloth or bedspread, it means that you need to click sooner. An early click will catch the dog just as he is emerging and give him the idea that peeking is what is being clicked.

trainingInfo.name: Who's a Brave Dog?
trainingInfo.description: This trick is similar to Are You Scared? except in this trick the dog runs around behind the handler and through his legs until she is looking up at the handler's face. The shaping steps to teach Who's a Brave Dog? are:

steps.step: Starting with your dog sitting in front of you, use a target stick to get your dog to go around you to the left or right.
Practice this until your dog will run behind your legs and touch the target for a click and treat.
Slowly move the target between your feet so that your dog comes between your legs enough to be able to look up at you.
Withhold the click after your dog starts to catch on to going through your legs and see if she will look up at you, then click and treat.
If your dog runs all the way through your legs, use the target stick to show her where she needs to stop and click and treat her before she actually touches it.
You can label this behavior Who's a Brave Dog? by saying the label right before you start the cue that starts the behavior, like pointing or whatever you did to encourage the dog to go around you.
Slowly fade the target as your dog starts to offer the behavior readily by showing the target to get her started and then making the target disappear.
Add distractions and be sure to go back to helping your dog with the target stick if the behavior falls apart.

tips: Social Graces: - If your dog has learned to shake hands and bow, you're on a roll. Next, you can certainly expand his social skills to include a few kisses and pleasant conversation. The joy of having a dog is your interaction with each other. The next two behaviors really make the most of that.

trainingInfo.name: Kiss Me
trainingInfo.description: Teaching this behavior utilizes a combination of free shaping and luring. You are catching the dog in the act of doing the behavior and rewarding it, but you are getting the behavior by started by prompting it first. The shaping steps for teaching Kiss Me are:

steps.step: Use food initially to excite your dog. This is key. Feed him a few small pieces of a treat and eat (or act like you do) a few yourself, then stick your chin out and wait.
At the first sign of any attempt to open his mouth to lick you, click and treat.
Try putting the treats in your mouth and showing him they're there. Click and treat any attempt to lick you.
Add the verbal cue Kiss right before you think he's going to offer the behavior. Click and treat as the behavior happens.
Fade the food by showing it to the dog and putting it away on a counter or table and commanding Kiss. When he kisses, click and treat and run and get the treat.
Repeat this until the dog is beginning to offer the kiss as soon as you stick out your chin.

trainingInfo.name: Speak
trainingInfo.description: Luring and free shaping, or combination of the two, are the best tools for teaching this trick. The trick itself requires your dog to bark on cue.

steps.step: Find something that causes your dog to bark, like a knock on the door holding a treat out of range. Click and treat her when when she barks.
Repeat at least twenty to twenty-five times.
Fake the antecedent to barking (the knock), and if your dogs starts to bark, click and treat.
Verbally label the behavior Speak just before your dog barks.
Don't click and treat for any barking other than the one you ask for.
If she barks at inappropriate times, be obvious about turning your upper body away to her know that extraneous barking will not be rewarded.

trainingInfo.conclusion: After basic obedience training skills (Sit, Stay, and Come), these simple (advance) tricks are the best opportunity for you and your dog to build a trusting and cooperative relationship. You'll develop a better understanding of how your dog thinks, and what motivates her, and your dog will learn to read your cues. Take the time to train your dog well; the benefits will last a lifetime! Your Ready to Learn More Tricks?: - Regardless of your dog's skill level, anyone can have fun teaching these simple (advance) tricks. Remember, the bottom line is to make sure you have fun while spending time with your best friend. Whether you teach your dog tricks to entertain your friends and family or you do therapy work in hospitals and nursing homes, having a dog who can do tricks shows off all her amazing attributes. Spending time together learning something new will enhance your bond and strengthen your relationship, making the quality of life better for both of you. Hopefully, you will enjoy teaching these Advance tricks, and it will inspire you to move on to the more complicated tricks and specialty training.
